title: 6 ways PLA filament is fine for 3D printing beginners but not for enthusiasts
description: 3D printing newbies should start with PLA, but be prepared to switch as you grow your skills in the hobby
author: Jeff Butts
excerpt: 3D printing newbies should start with PLA, but be prepared to switch as you grow your skills in the hobby
text: PLA filament is the go-to material for beginners to 3D printing, and for good reason. It's easy to print, requires minimal fine-tuning, and works well with most consumer-grade printers. However, as users become more experienced and demand more from their prints, PLA's limitations start to show. It lacks durability, struggles in high temperatures, and offers limited post-processing options compared to other filaments. While PLA is great for learning the basics, enthusiasts often move on to materials like PETG, ABS, or even exotic filaments for better performance. Whether you're looking for heat resistance, impact strength, or aesthetic versatility, PLA can feel like a limiting factor rather than a helpful tool. Here’s why PLA works well for beginners but often frustrates experienced 3D printing enthusiasts. Related 6 PLA supports speed but lacks flexibility Prints fast but not for flexible or impact-resistant parts PLA can be printed quickly with minimal risk of deformation, making it great for rapid prototyping. Many entry-level printers can push PLA at high speeds while maintaining decent quality. This makes it a good choice for beginners who want to see results fast without spending time optimizing settings. However, PLA lacks flexibility and impact resistance, making it unsuitable for functional parts that need to absorb stress. If you need a print that bends without breaking, TPU or PETG are far better choices. PLA’s rigidity is a downside for moving parts, joints, or anything that needs to withstand repeated stress. Enthusiasts often look for more versatile materials to expand their printing possibilities beyond simple static objects. 5 An inexpensive material, but limits advanced printing techniques Great for budget printing but bad for experimentation Source: Maker 101 / YouTube 3D printing the face mask One of PLA’s biggest appeals is its affordability. It’s one of the cheapest filaments available, making it ideal for beginners who don’t want to waste expensive material while learning. Since it prints with fewer failed attempts, it’s also cost-effective for quick prototyping. PLA can be restrictive for enthusiasts who want to push the limits of 3D printing. It doesn’t support advanced techniques like annealing for added strength and struggles with high-speed printing compared to tougher filaments. While some modified PLAs offer slightly better performance, they don’t match materials like PETG or ABS in advanced applications. Enthusiasts experimenting with multi-material printing, flexible filaments, or high-temperature composites often find PLA too basic. It’s okay for simple prints, but PLA quickly becomes a bottleneck once you explore more complex techniques. 4 PLA has a low learning curve but limits design freedom Easy to begin with but restricts complex builds PLA’s low learning curve makes it perfect for beginners. It adheres well to the print bed, doesn’t require an enclosure, and works with nearly all entry-level printers. The lack of warping issues means even those with minimal experience can achieve successful prints without much troubleshooting. PLA’s limitations become apparent for enthusiasts who want to print large or intricate models. Compared to materials like PETG, which can handle longer spans without sagging, PLA struggles with bridging and overhangs. Supports can also be more challenging to remove cleanly, especially compared to soluble support materials like PVA. If you push the limits with complex, high-detail prints, PLA can feel like a constraint rather than a tool. 3 It makes printing easy but lacks durability Great for quick prints, bad for long-term strength One of the most significant advantages of PLA is how easy it is to print. It doesn’t require a heated bed, adheres well to most surfaces, and prints at relatively low temperatures. This makes it perfect for beginners who want to start printing without warping or nozzle clogging. PLA’s low shrinkage also means that dimensional accuracy is usually on point. However, PLA’s convenience comes at a cost. It’s brittle and prone to breaking under stress, making it a poor choice for mechanical parts or functional prototypes. Enthusiasts who want to print strong, durable objects often turn to PETG or ABS instead. Even for decorative prints, PLA’s fragility can be frustrating if a small drop or impact ruins a model. Another downside is that PLA degrades over time, especially in humid environments. Unlike materials designed for long-term durability, PLA can become weak and brittle after prolonged exposure to moisture. This limits its usefulness for projects that need to stand the test of time. 2 PLA sticks well but suffers from layer adhesion issues Beginner-friendly adhesion but weak layer bonding One of the reasons PLA is great for beginners is its ability to stick well to most print beds without a heated surface. This reduces failed prints and makes it easier to get good first layers. A well-calibrated printer can produce high-detail PLA prints with minimal effort. Unfortunately, PLA's layer adhesion isn’t as strong as that of materials like ABS or PETG. Under stress, PLA prints often split along layer lines, leading to premature failure. This makes it a poor choice for load-bearing prints or functional parts that must withstand force. Enthusiasts looking for strong, durable prints often find PLA unreliable in real-world applications. 1 Filament that prints well but melts too easily PLA works at low temperatures but fails in heat PLA’s low melting point makes it beginner-friendly. It prints at temperatures as low as 180°C, reducing the risk of hot-end damage and simplifying cooling. This leads to sharper details and fewer printing issues. Many budget-friendly printers are optimized for PLA, making it the most accessible filament for new users. The problem is that PLA softens at around 60°C, meaning it can’t withstand much heat before deforming. Leaving a PLA print in a hot car or near a heat source can cause it to warp or collapse. This makes it a terrible choice for functional parts that need to withstand moderate temperatures, such as car accessories, enclosures, or tool handles. Enthusiasts often want their prints to last in different environments, not just sit on a shelf—many move on to PETG, ABS, or Nylon, which offer much better heat resistance. While PLA is fine for small decorative models, its inability to handle heat makes it a poor choice for advanced applications. PLA is fine for learning but not for pushing limits PLA is the perfect filament for beginners, offering ease of use, affordability, and reliable printing. It’s an excellent material for learning the fundamentals of 3D printing without dealing with complicated settings or material-specific challenges. It works well for basic models, prototypes, and decorative prints. However, as printing skills improve, PLA’s weaknesses become more evident. Its lack of durability, low heat resistance, and limited post-processing options make it a frustrating material for enthusiasts who want to push the boundaries of what 3D printing can do. While it’s great for starting, most experienced users eventually move on to more advanced filaments that offer better performance and flexibility.
html:
PLA filament is the go-to material for beginners to 3D printing, and for good reason. It's easy to print, requires minimal fine-tuning, and works well with most consumer-grade printers. However, as users become more experienced and demand more from their prints, PLA's limitations start to show. It lacks durability, struggles in high temperatures, and offers limited post-processing options compared to other filaments.

While PLA is great for learning the basics, enthusiasts often move on to materials like PETG, ABS, or even exotic filaments for better performance. Whether you're looking for heat resistance, impact strength, or aesthetic versatility, PLA can feel like a limiting factor rather than a helpful tool. Here’s why PLA works well for beginners but often frustrates experienced 3D printing enthusiasts.

Related

6 PLA supports speed but lacks flexibility

Prints fast but not for flexible or impact-resistant parts

PLA can be printed quickly with minimal risk of deformation, making it great for rapid prototyping. Many entry-level printers can push PLA at high speeds while maintaining decent quality. This makes it a good choice for beginners who want to see results fast without spending time optimizing settings.

However, PLA lacks flexibility and impact resistance, making it unsuitable for functional parts that need to absorb stress. If you need a print that bends without breaking, TPU or PETG are far better choices. PLA’s rigidity is a downside for moving parts, joints, or anything that needs to withstand repeated stress. Enthusiasts often look for more versatile materials to expand their printing possibilities beyond simple static objects.

5 An inexpensive material, but limits advanced printing techniques

Great for budget printing but bad for experimentation

3D printing the face mask

One of PLA’s biggest appeals is its affordability. It’s one of the cheapest filaments available, making it ideal for beginners who don’t want to waste expensive material while learning. Since it prints with fewer failed attempts, it’s also cost-effective for quick prototyping.

PLA can be restrictive for enthusiasts who want to push the limits of 3D printing. It doesn’t support advanced techniques like annealing for added strength and struggles with high-speed printing compared to tougher filaments. While some modified PLAs offer slightly better performance, they don’t match materials like PETG or ABS in advanced applications.

Enthusiasts experimenting with multi-material printing, flexible filaments, or high-temperature composites often find PLA too basic. It’s okay for simple prints, but PLA quickly becomes a bottleneck once you explore more complex techniques.

4 PLA has a low learning curve but limits design freedom

Easy to begin with but restricts complex builds

PLA’s low learning curve makes it perfect for beginners. It adheres well to the print bed, doesn’t require an enclosure, and works with nearly all entry-level printers. The lack of warping issues means even those with minimal experience can achieve successful prints without much troubleshooting.

PLA’s limitations become apparent for enthusiasts who want to print large or intricate models. Compared to materials like PETG, which can handle longer spans without sagging, PLA struggles with bridging and overhangs. Supports can also be more challenging to remove cleanly, especially compared to soluble support materials like PVA. If you push the limits with complex, high-detail prints, PLA can feel like a constraint rather than a tool.

3 It makes printing easy but lacks durability

Great for quick prints, bad for long-term strength

One of the most significant advantages of PLA is how easy it is to print. It doesn’t require a heated bed, adheres well to most surfaces, and prints at relatively low temperatures. This makes it perfect for beginners who want to start printing without warping or nozzle clogging. PLA’s low shrinkage also means that dimensional accuracy is usually on point.

However, PLA’s convenience comes at a cost. It’s brittle and prone to breaking under stress, making it a poor choice for mechanical parts or functional prototypes. Enthusiasts who want to print strong, durable objects often turn to PETG or ABS instead. Even for decorative prints, PLA’s fragility can be frustrating if a small drop or impact ruins a model.

Another downside is that PLA degrades over time, especially in humid environments. Unlike materials designed for long-term durability, PLA can become weak and brittle after prolonged exposure to moisture. This limits its usefulness for projects that need to stand the test of time.

2 PLA sticks well but suffers from layer adhesion issues

Beginner-friendly adhesion but weak layer bonding

One of the reasons PLA is great for beginners is its ability to stick well to most print beds without a heated surface. This reduces failed prints and makes it easier to get good first layers. A well-calibrated printer can produce high-detail PLA prints with minimal effort.

Unfortunately, PLA's layer adhesion isn’t as strong as that of materials like ABS or PETG. Under stress, PLA prints often split along layer lines, leading to premature failure. This makes it a poor choice for load-bearing prints or functional parts that must withstand force. Enthusiasts looking for strong, durable prints often find PLA unreliable in real-world applications.

1 Filament that prints well but melts too easily

PLA works at low temperatures but fails in heat

PLA’s low melting point makes it beginner-friendly. It prints at temperatures as low as 180°C, reducing the risk of hot-end damage and simplifying cooling. This leads to sharper details and fewer printing issues. Many budget-friendly printers are optimized for PLA, making it the most accessible filament for new users.

The problem is that PLA softens at around 60°C, meaning it can’t withstand much heat before deforming. Leaving a PLA print in a hot car or near a heat source can cause it to warp or collapse. This makes it a terrible choice for functional parts that need to withstand moderate temperatures, such as car accessories, enclosures, or tool handles.

Enthusiasts often want their prints to last in different environments, not just sit on a shelf—many move on to PETG, ABS, or Nylon, which offer much better heat resistance. While PLA is fine for small decorative models, its inability to handle heat makes it a poor choice for advanced applications.

PLA is fine for learning but not for pushing limits

PLA is the perfect filament for beginners, offering ease of use, affordability, and reliable printing. It’s an excellent material for learning the fundamentals of 3D printing without dealing with complicated settings or material-specific challenges. It works well for basic models, prototypes, and decorative prints.

However, as printing skills improve, PLA’s weaknesses become more evident. Its lack of durability, low heat resistance, and limited post-processing options make it a frustrating material for enthusiasts who want to push the boundaries of what 3D printing can do. While it’s great for starting, most experienced users eventually move on to more advanced filaments that offer better performance and flexibility.
